CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The Superintendent Search Advisory Committee  advised the board throughout the selection process and was instrumental in the development of a Request for Proposal (RFP) to hire an outside consultant to conduct educational partner engagement in May and June 2021; participation in multiple community outreach opportunities from July to September 2021; review of the consultant's report on community feedback in October 2021; development of the Superintendent job posting in October 2021; review of application packages in November 2021; recommendation of up to 10 finalists in December 2021; development of a community forum model during December 2021 and January 2022; and participation in the community forum in February 2022.  

 

BACKGROUND: In February 2021, the board created an Advisory Committee comprised of community and educational partners to facilitate the selection process for the next permanent San Diego Unified Superintendent, upon the resignation of Cindy Marten who was ultimately appointed to the position of US Deputy Secretary of Education in May 2021.

C. Student Presentations, Recognitions, and Resolutions
Subject
3. Recognition of Employees for Years of Service (40, 30, 20, 15, 10 and 5 Years of Service)
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: As a service-providing organization, the San Diego Unified School District's employees are its most valuable resource. Today's recognition includes recognition of employees with 40, 30, 20, 15, 10 and 5 years of service. The Superintendent and the Board of Education extend their most sincere gratitude to these individuals. 

 

Today, we celebrate the milestones of 67 employees.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Monthly recognition, meant to celebrate and acknowledge employees who have hit notable career milestones with the district. In appreciation of their commitment to San Diego Unified, the program awards a service pin for an employee's 5, 10, 15, 20, 30 and 40 year service anniversary.

 

In an effort to honor and feature as many employees as possible in the virtual celebration, all employees reaching milestones are invited to submit a self-recorded video for inclusion in the recognition portion of the board meeting. The video is also shared on the district's Employee Recognition web page. 

 

*This service recognition award is not used to calculate or verify the seniority date of an employee nor is the recognition part of the formal personnel processes that calculate the date for longevity pay. Both longevity and seniority dates are dictated by the Education Code as well as the applicable collective bargaining agreement. The date used to determine this service award is based on the individual's permanent status as an employee, temporary or hourly work is not used in the determination of the service award recognition. Service recognition awards will be awarded on a monthly basis. If you believe an error has been made, you may contact the Human Resource Service Division by emailing jobs@sandi.net.

 

Click this link to view the March 2022 Milestone Video

 

Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resources Officer, 619.725.8043, athede@sandi.net

E. Student Instructional Matters
Subject
3. A-G Completion Improvement Grant (First Reading)
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information, First Reading

RECOMMENDATION: First Reading and Discussion of the A-G Completion Improvement Grant Plan.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $12,866,191.00. Revenue Strings: 

0000-74120-00-8590-0000-0000-01000-0000, $11,201,623.00

0000-74130-00-8590-0000-0000-01000-0000, $1,664,568.00

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The following is San Diego Unified's plan for the A-G Completion Improvement Grant. The plan will explain how the district will use the funds it receives through the A-G Completion Improvement Grant to directly support pupil access to, and successful completion of, the A-G course requirements. The plan will further explain how the district will use funds to provide teachers, administrators, and counselors with professional learning opportunities to improve A-G completion rate, develop comprehensive advising plans and pupil supports, including tutoring programs, to improve the local educational agency's A-G completion rate and expand access to coursework or other opportunities to satisfy A-G course requirements to all pupils, including, but not necessarily limited to, unduplicated pupils (i.e., multilingual learners, foster, homeless military, and migrant youth, students with disabilities, and students who are below grade level, including, but not limited to credit-deficient students, high school students at risk of not graduating, and other students identified by staff). An overview of the plan was first presented to the Board on March 8, 2022.

 

[Originator/Contact: Jennifer Roberson, Instructional Support Officer (TOC), Leadership and Learning, jroberson@sandi.net]

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
3. Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing Thursday, March 31, 2022, as Cesar E. Chavez Day of Service and Learning
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing Thursday, March 31, 2022, as Cesar E. Chavez Day of Service and Learning, and encourage student participation in authorized school community service honoring the life and work of César E. Chavez. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The son of migrant farm workers, César E. Chavez learned about the oppression of field laborers firsthand and directed his life goals and aspirations toward educating his fellow farm workers to understand their rights to a safe workplace and a just wage. In 1962, César E. Chavez founded the United Farm Workers of America. From his studies in civic action and his study of the work of Gandhi and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Chavez developed and adhered to principles of non-violence in his crusade for peace and justice. César E. Chavez said, “Real education should consist of drawing the goodness and the best out of our own students. What better book can there be than the book of humanity.” César E. Chavez and legions of loyal supporters dedicated themselves to the education of migrant workers and their children through the establishment of better schools, fighting to empower farm workers through voter registration, and teaching community members how to organize themselves to effectively represent their interests with government, school, and financial institutions. California schools are authorized to commemorate César E. Chavez with student community service projects and are directed to provide instruction on the farm labor movement in the United States and the role of César E. Chavez. The successful leadership development of César E. Chavez Service Clubs, organized by San Diego Unified and Urban Corps of San Diego, are now being emulated in California’s most populated cities throughout the state. San Diego Unified dedicated César E. Chavez Elementary School, in September 1997, to provide an education program for more than 500 students. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Board of Education Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

1. Ratification of Tentative Agreement with the Administrators Association of San Diego (AASD) Certificated Bargaining Unit Regarding Summer Programs; Approve the Revised Site Administrator Salary Plan and Position Descriptions
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$223,202.49

RECOMMENDATION: Ratification of the Tentative Agreement with the Administrators Association San Diego City Schools (AASD) Certificated Bargaining Unit regarding Summer Programs; approve the revised Site Administrator Salary Plan and Position Descriptions.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $223,202.49

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: Approval of this agreement provides Associate Principals and Site-Based Instructional Coordinators with leadership development opportunities aligned to Goal 4 of the LCAP. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Goal 3 of the LCAP commits to design expanded learning opportunities that accelerate learning, enhance connections to the school community, and reignite passion for learning. Goal 4 of the LCAP includes commitments to developing leadership development opportunities to ensure the retention of our leaders. This agreement supports both of these goals by ensuring high-quality leaders work with our summer programs. The District and the AASD Certificated bargaining unit met to discuss summer programs.  After bargaining in good faith, the parties reached an agreement on specific terms and conditions of employment related to summer programs.  The agreement is attached to this Board item and has been approved by the bargaining unit.

Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Administrators Association San Diego City Schools (AASD) Certificated and Classified Supervisors Bargaining Units regarding the Impacts and Effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: No budget adjustments are required for this agreement as existing budget covers any fiscal impact.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: The impacts and effects to District staff are outlined in this MOU. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: In order to promote public health, the safety of employees, and to ensure the continuity of learning for students, the District met with each of the bargaining units to discuss the District’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic. After bargaining in good faith, the District reached agreements with each bargaining unit on specific terms regarding the impacts and effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. The agreement is attached to this Board item and has been approved by the individual bargaining unit.  

 

 

Attached is the following document:

 

  • AASD Certificated and Classified- Impacts and Effects of the Temporary Deployment of Central Office Staff to School Sites

 

The District continues to meet with each of the bargaining units to reach agreements related to the impacts and effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and will continue to bring completed agreements for Board approval.

4. Independent Citizens Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity: Update to the Board
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Information

RECOMMENDATION: This item is presented for information only. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity prepared this presentation on March 9, 2022 during its regularly scheduled meeting.

 

BACKGROUND: The Independent Citizens' Oversight Committee on Racial Justice and Equity holds the San Diego Unified School District accountable to the public on whether we are making progress in the following areas:

  • Interrupting Discriminatory Grading Practices
  • Dismantling Discriminatory Discipline Policies and Practices
  • Implementation of Ethnic Studies for All Students
  • Transformation of School Police
  • Staff Diversity

Per the Board of Education's direction on July 21, 2020, the Committee will have analyze data that is necessary to monitor progress and report back to the public and make recommendations. The Committee will annually report whether or not the District is making progress. For the 2022 calendar year, the ICOC will receive a staff report and will also hear from a student focus group who will share their lived experiences on our campuses. Each focus group will address one of the five areas of focus for this committee. The combination of data and student voice will assist the committee in its duties in reporting to the Board.

 

[Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resource Officer, athede@sandi.net]

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: At the February 22, 2022 board of education meeting, trustees approved the reappointment of representatives to the Prop S, Prop Z, and Measure YY Independent Citizens Oversight Committee (ICOC).  At the time, staff advised board trustees that a subsequent recommendation would be forthcoming for the Charter School Facilities Committee representative to the ICOC.  At its February 24, 2022 meeting, the Charter School Facility Committee (CSFC) voted unanimously to recommend trustees appoint Miles Durfee at the CSFC representative to the ICOC.  Separately, the CSFC voted unanimously to recommend trustees reappoint Christine Kane, Alexa Greenland, Joel Christman, and Eric Premack.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

BACKGROUND: With the passage of Proposition Z on November 6, 2012, the San Diego Unified School District specifically allocated $350 million of the $2.8 billion total bond authorization toward the completion of facility projects at public charter school sites located within the district. Through the passage of Measure YY on November 6, 2018, the San Diego Unified School District allocated $588 million of the $3.5 billion total bond authorization toward the implementation of projects at public charter schools authorized by, and located within the district boundaries.


On September 4, 2012, the board passed a resolution establishing the San Diego Unified School District Charter School Facility Committee for the purpose of providing recommendations to the board on the use of Proposition Z funds to improve capital facilities located at charter school sites. By resolution on May 14, 2019, the board expanded the purview of the committee by including Measure YY. Under the resolution the committee was to be comprised of seven members, including five charter school board members or employees, and two individuals with expertise, knowledge or background related to charter school operations/facilities.


Pursuant to the resolution, committee members were appointed to two-year terms by the Board. The first terms were staggered such that three members were initially appointed to one-year terms. On February 26, 2013, the board appointed all seven members of the committee to one and two-year terms consistent with the resolution.

FISCAL IMPACT: Cost to relocate district uses in classrooms identified for occupancy by the charter schools to be determined. No facilities changes anticipated. Revenue will also be generated in the amount of 2 percent of the charter schools' LCFF revenues, based on the amount of their enrollment that occupies the space provided.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: Approximately $292 in General Funds.  

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  

Proposition 39 (Education Code section 47614) requires the district to offer reasonably equivalent facilities to charter schools that show that they are eligible to receive such facilities. At its January 25, 2022 meeting, the board approved district staff recommendations for the preliminary proposals of facilities to eligible charter schools that made appropriate and timely applications for facilities under the provisions of California Education Code section 47614 and California Code of Regulations, Title 5, sections 11969 et seq.

 

Staff analyzed each of the Charters' responses to the preliminary proposal in conformity with the requirements of Education code section 47614 and the implementing regulations and developed recommendations for the final offers of facilities for eligible charter schools. Staff is submitting this report and its recommendations for board approval and requests the board adopt the report as its statement of reasons.

 

Based on the Charters' responses to the preliminary proposals and subsequent correspondence between the District and Charter Schools, the final offers are substantially the same as the previously-approved preliminary proposals.

 

Education Code section 47614 and the California Code Regulations Title 5 sections 11969 et seq. (Regulations) require 1) that Charter schools must respond to the final offer by May 1, if they intend to receive district facilities for the upcoming year.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: 

The allocation of district facilities to charter schools pursuant to Proposition 39 constitutes a project for the purposes of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code section 21000 et seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended.

 

On June 23, 2020, the board adopted the Lindbergh/Schweitzer Whole Site Modernization and Joint Use Field Project Mitigated Negative Declaration Addendum 1, which included the expansion of the Kavod Charter School by up to 23 classrooms. The board directed staff to file a CEQA Notice of Determination (NOD) with the County Recorder/Clerk which occurred on June 29, 2020 (Attachment 1). 

 

On March 10, 2020, the board adopted a Notice of Exemption (NOE) for Elevate Charter School at Vista Grande Elementary School Relocatable and Shade Structure Project. This project considered the existing Elevate Charter school operations which included five classrooms and one relocatable building. The board directed staff to file the NOE with the County Recorder/Clerk, which occurred on March 11, 2020 (Attachment 2).

 

On May 15, 2018, the board adopted the Twain Main Portable Campus Project Negative Declaration, which included construction of 13 portable classrooms, one administration building, and one relocatable restroom at the existing Twain Main High School Campus. The Board directed staff to file a CEQA NOD with the County Recorder/Clerk which occurred on May 16, 2018 (Attachment 3). Empower Charter School would occupy the existing remaining portable classrooms consistent with the previously approved Twain Main Portable Campus Project.

 

On March 13, 2018, the board adopted an NOE for the Allocation of Charter Facilities Use Permit Agreements, which included the allocation of 10 classrooms for the Holly Drive Leadership Academy at Webster Elementary. The board directed staff to file the NOE with the County Recorder/Clerk which occurred on March 15, 2018 (Attachment 4).

 

On April 14, 2020, the board adopted an NOE for the allocation of facilities under Proposition 39 for Iftin Charter School, for up to 20 total classrooms. The board directed staff to file the NOE with the County Recorder/Clerk which occurred on September 17, 2020 (Attachment 5). The 2022 allocation includes two additional classrooms (22 total), which is within the thresholds for the Class 14 Categorical exemption that was approved previously.

 

Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the allocation of district facilities for Elevate School, Empower Language Academy, Holly Drive Leadership Academy, Iftin Charter School, and Kavod Charter School are consistent with the previously approved projects, were fully analyzed in the referenced CEQA documents, and no further CEQA review is required. 

  

[Originator/Contact: Regina Rega, Manager, Instructional Facilities Planning Department, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 619.725.7370, rrega@sandi.net]

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Resolution delegating authority to Alicia Rolfe, Controller, to be the Plan Administrator for San Diego Unified School District's 403(b) and 457 Tax-Sheltered Annuity Plans, effective February 8, 2022. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Among the benefits offered by the district to its employees is the opportunity to make pre-tax contributions to 403(b) and 457(b) tax sheltered annuity plans.  Authorization for employee withdrawals of their individual tax-sheltered annuity monies require the signature of a Plan Administrator designated by the district with delegated authority to do so.  In San Diego Unified, this authority is traditionally assigned to its Controller.  Alicia Rolfe was appointed the district's Controller on February 8, 2022.  This Resolution effectuates the district's delegation of authority to Alicia Rolfe as Plan Administrator of the district's 403(b) and 457 tax-sheltered annuity plans, effective February 8, 2022.

14. Accept, Budget, and Spend Income Summary for January 2022; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS FUNDS
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,507,562.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Accept, Budget, and Spend Income Summary for January 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $1,507,562.00. Budget String: Various funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Actions to accept, budget, and spend income, in excess of that included in the adopted budget, are authorized by Education Code section 42602. These actions provide the means by which the Board of Education can access income which becomes available to them after they have adopted a final budget. When such added income is available and a majority of the board is in agreement as to its use, the action to accept, budget, and spend the income is a routine action. It increases the budgeted appropriations in the amount of the added income and authorizes the expenditure of that income for the purposes designated in the resolution and supporting budget.

 

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619.725.7171, arolfe@sandi.net]

Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applcable

RECOMMENDATION: Authorize multiple vendors to provide underwriting services in support of the issuance of General Obligation (GO) Bonds and Tax Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANs), and to provide related financial services. Authorize the execution of any documents that are necessary to effectuate these services. The term of this authorization is March 23, 2022 through March 22, 2025 with two additional one-year options.

 

  1. BofA Securities
  2. Citigroup Global Markets, Inc.
  3. Goldman Sachs & Co., LLC
  4. JP Morgan
  5. Jefferies, LLC
  6. Siebert Williams Shank
  7. Stifel Nicolaus & Company

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. There is no direct fiscal impact to the General Fund. Any compensation due from the district that results from the provision of services by any of these providers will be paid as part of the respective transaction for General Obligation (GO) bonds, Tax Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANs), or other financial transactions.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: Prior underwriting services were paid from the respective financial transaction.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: It is necessary to establish a pool of firms to provide underwriting services to support the district with services relating to debt issuances, such as General Obligation (GO) bonds and Tax Revenue Anticipation Notes (TRANs). Fifteen firms responded to a competitive Request for Qualifications/Proposal (RFQ/P) (No. PS22-0712-18) released on January 26, 2022 and February 2, 2022: AmeriVet Securities, Barclays, BofA Securities, Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., Goldman Sachs & Co., LLC, JP Morgan, Jefferies, LLC, Mischler Financial Group, Inc., Piper Sandler & Company, Raymond James & Associates, Inc., Rice Securities, LLC, Siebert Williams Shank, Stifel Nicolaus & Company, UBS Financial Services and Wells Fargo.  

The proposals received from these firms were evaluated by KNN Finance, the district's Financial Advisor, district's Controller and Executive Director, Finance Division, in order to establish a short list of firms to then be interviewed. The short list consisted of 11 firms: Barclays, BofA Securities, Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., Goldman Sachs & Co., LLC, JP Morgan, Jefferies, LLC,  Raymond James & Associates, Inc., Siebert Williams Shank, Stifel Nicolaus & Company, UBS Financial Services and Wells Fargo.

These 11 proposers were subsequently interviewed by an Evaluation Committee consisting of Jodie Macalos, Executive Director, Finance Division Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division; Mark Young, KNN Public Finance; Larry Lom, KNN Public Finance; Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities, Planning & Construction; and the San Diego County Treasurer-Tax Collector's Office. Based upon these interviews, the Evaluation Committee recommends that it is in the best interest of the district to authorize the provision of underwriting services from the following firms: BofA Securities, Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., Goldman Sachs & Co., LLC, JP Morgan, Jefferies, LLC, Siebert Williams Shank and Stifel Nicolaus & Company.

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619.725.7171, arolfe@sandi.net]

Driver, LLC, to provide construction services for the Franklin Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project (Lease-Leaseback) (CZ20-0390-08.A2). The term of the Agreement is March 22, 2022 and continues until the project is complete. All other terms and conditions will remain the same under the original Agreement.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $38,498,500.77. This total not-to exceed amount includes:

Allowances $820,000.00;

Budget Strings:

9113-90112-00-6230-8500-0000-21312-8XXX Proposition S

9113-90402-00-6230-8500-0000-21400-8XXX Proposition Z

9113-90502-00-6230-8500-0000-21500-8XXX Measure YY


PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: Approved by board: December 10, 2019: Original contract value: $268,466.00 – Preconstruction Services.

.

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.  

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On December 10, 2019, district entered into Master Site Lease and Master Facilities Lease-Leaseback Agreements with C.W. Driver, LLC, to provide preconstruction for the Franklin Elementary School Whole Site Modernization (Lease-Leaseback) project as a result of a SOQ and RFP Lease-Leaseback delivery method process.

 

On February 25, 2020, district entered into First Amendment to Master Facilities Lease-Leaseback Agreement with C.W. Driver, LLC to allow preconstruction services to be invoiced as progress payments based on percentage of completion. This amendment required Contractor to provide a total fixed fee cost for preconstruction services based on anticipated hours of work and the identified deliverables. This amendment was not substantive, but simply to allow the billing methodology to be simplified for both parties.

 

The District and C.W. Driver, LLC, now further desire to amend the Master Site Lease to this First Amendment and the Master Facilities Lease to this Amended and Restated to incorporate administrative and other non-substantive changes to match the current district standards for Lease-Leaseback contracts and to include the Guaranteed Maximum Price for the construction of whole site modernization portion of work which includes demolition of two buildings to accommodate a new two-story building with classrooms, kitchen, staff lounge, and restrooms.  Modernization will also be completed to several of the existing buildings, as well as related site work for Franklin Elementary School WSM – GMP No. 1 Project.

 

On May 10, 2011, the board approved a resolution in support of service-disabled, veterans-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, C.W. Driver, submitted a 7.5 percent DVBE participation in its proposal.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the amended Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000, et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2, et. seq., as amended). On December 10, 2019, the board approved a resolution adopting a Final Mitigated Negative Declaration (MND) and adopting a Mitigation Monitoring and Reporting Program for the Franklin Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Determination (Attached) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County and the California State Clearinghouse, Office of Planning and Research, which was completed on December 11, 2019. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the amendment to the Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the above referenced IS/MND, and no further CEQA review is required.

RECOMMENDATIONS: Approve Agreements with CALSTART, Inc. to share data collected for the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project to California Air Resources Board (CARB) and other project-related stakeholders (PS22-0659-11) and for plug-in electric vehicle telematics usage to connect data logging devices for the purpose of data collection efforts under the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project for the California Air Resources Board (CARB) Grant (PS22-0799-11). The term of these Agreements is March 22, 2022 through March 31, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On February 11, 2020, the board approved a resolution to authorize an Agreement to accept grant funds from the California Air Resources Board (CARB) for the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project to reduce the district’s carbon footprint by replacing existing diesel and/or gasoline-powered mobility vehicles and other equipment with electric vehicles, with the objective to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the schools in the Lincoln High School cluster.

 

On September 8, 2020, the board ratified an Agreement with CalStart, Inc. (PS20-1267-40) to provide project management, data collection, and reporting for the California Air Resources Board (CARB) Grant for a term of April 1, 2020 through March 31, 2023, with a total not-to-exceed dollar amount of $560,000.00.

 

On June 8, 2021, the board approved the First Amendment to the Agreement with CalStart, Inc. (PS20-1267-40)to increase the consideration by $50,000.00, for a new total not-to-exceed dollar amount of $610,000.00. The term remained unchanged.

 

CALSTART, Inc. is comprised of a team of emissions data analytics experts who will oversee all emissions data gathering, analysis, and reporting. CALSTART, Inc. will receive and track all project data for emissions reduction reporting. Data items collected will include reduced electrical demand, shifts in processes toward zero-emission, and cost savings from on-site generation, storage, and production. These results will be submitted to CARB at the required times and reported out at the project’s Technical Assistance Committee to help shape the overall project reporting.

 

These two Agreements with CALSTRAT, Inc. are in conjunction with the same efforts and will allow CALSTART, Inc. to continue performing data collection, clean-up, uploading data to a database, and analysis of data to determine the current state of practice, operating characteristics, business case, and to identify opportunities for improvement resulting in a summary report/presentation to be provided to the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and other project-related stakeholders; as well as allow telematics usage to connect data logging for the devices for medium to heavy vehicles to collect data for the purposes of the Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Project for the CARB grant.

RECOMMENDATION: Approve First Amendment to Master Site Lease and Amended and Restated Master Facilities Lease Agreements with Sundt Construction, Inc., to provide construction services for Morse High School Phase III New Administration Building 1800 and Portable Building B34 Renovation (Lease-Leaseback) CZ20-0641-42.A2. The term of this Agreement is effective March 22, 2022 and continues until the Project is complete. All other terms and conditions will remain the same under the original Agreement.

 

FISCAL IMPACT:  Total not-to-exceed: $59,704,999.12. This total no-to-exceed amount includes:

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

Approved by the board on November 12, 2019 – Total not to exceed amount of $9,113,316.83 for the construction services for Morse High School Phase II Whole Site Modernization ($8,608,332.83) and preconstruction services for Morse High School Phase III New Administration Building 1800 and Portable Building B34 Renovation ($504,984.00).

 

Approved by the board on November 9, 2021 – Total not to exceed amount of $32,705.00 for additional preconstruction services for Morse High School Phase III New Administration Building 1800 and Portable Building B34 Renovation.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On September 12, 2017, the board passed a resolution adopting new procedures for evaluating the qualifications of lease-leaseback contractors and the issuance of a request to prequalify and statement of qualifications for certain district projects. That resolution authorized the Superintendent to have staff implement the evaluation procedures and make revisions to the criteria that did not impact the overall fair and impartial procurement solicitation process.

 

On September 14, 2017, the district issued a Request to Prequalify and for Statement of Qualifications for Preliminary and Construction Services for Certain District Projects (Lease-Leaseback) (“RFQ”) to create a list of the highest-ranking respondents, based on best value selection criteria, to serve as Qualified Lease-Leaseback Contractors for potential engagement for two years.

 

On October 6, 2017, 12 contractors submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQs) to the district’s RFQ. After evaluating each of the SOQs under the established criteria and procedures, district staff determined that six of the contractors met the requirements of the RFQ.

 

On September 10, 2019, the board approved to extend through March 31, 2020 (approximately five months) the Lease-Leaseback selected pool of General Contractors known as Group A, in order to complete the solicitation for the Morse High School Whole Site Modernization, as the two-year eligibility period for the Group A was set to expire on October 18, 2019. 

 

On November 12, 2019, as a result of a Request for Proposals (RFP) process, the board approved an agreement with Sundt Construction, Inc., to provide construction services for the Morse High School Whole Site Modernization Phase II and preconstruction services for Morse High School New Administration Building and Theater Phase III Lease-Leaseback (LLB) Project.

 

On November 9, 2021, the board approved the First Amendment to the Master Facilities Lease with Sundt Construction, Inc., to continue providing Preconstruction Design Services for Morse High School New Administration Building and Theater Phase III.

 

Sundt Construction, Inc., has completed the preconstruction services for the Morse High School Phase III New Administration Building 1800 and Portable Building B34 Renovation (GMP No. 1) and the Division of the State Architect (DSA) has approved plans and specifications. On January 20, 2022, Sundt Construction, Inc., competitively bid out the construction portion of work to subcontractors to obtain the total value of their Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP No. 1) for Morse High School Phase III New Administration Building 1800 and Portable Building B34 Renovation.

 

The district and Sundt Construction, Inc., now desire to restate the Original Master Facilities Lease in its entirety, together with the First Amendment to Master Facilities, as part of this certain Amended and Restated Master Facilities Lease to include the Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP No.1) for the Project. The parties also wish to revise the Master Site Lease as a First Amendment to update force majeure and hazardous materials sections and to update the scope of work to include the GMP No. 1.

 

The district is using Propositions S, Z and Measure YY funds to repair, renovate and revitalize district schools. The existing buildings at Morse High School were originally built from 1962 – 2010. While the school has received upgrades and improvements over the years, the Long-Range Facility Master Plan showed that the site needs significant improvements.

 

The project consists of abatement and demolition of existing Administration Building, covered canopies, 12 portable classrooms, associated sitework and utilities, construction of new Administration Building and Performing Arts Center Building; renovation and construction of new campus entrance drop off parking lots and associated sitework; establishment of campus-wide low-voltage systems (new and existing) from the MDF in Building 800; demolition of existing minimum point of entry (MPOE), old MDF and low-voltage system equipment in old Administration Building; and removal of all low-voltage system backbone cabling emanating from old Administration Building.

 

Furthermore, it consists of: interior renovation of Building 1800 - Rooms 418 and 420 and B34, including demolition of fixed laboratory tables and casework and associated electrical, gas and plumbing; replacement of floor finish and ceiling panels, paint of new walls; and renovation of existing site accessible path of travel from Building 1800 Rooms 418 and 420 doors to the nearest accessible path of travel.

 

The construction sequence and project schedule are extremely important. The project will be completed in different parts due to the continued use of the site and facilities during the construction period. It is important to follow the phasing plan and keep the work on schedule. 

 

The design intent is to have a seamless transition for all improvement work required to be constructed on the school site.

 

On May 10, 2011, the board approved a resolution in support of service-disabled, veterans-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. Sundt Construction, Inc., submitted seven-point eight nine percent (7.89%) DVBE participation in its proposal for the Morse High School Phase II and a three-point zero seven percent (3.07%) DVBE participation for the Morse High School Phase III New Administration Building 1800 and Portable Building B34 Renovation.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed amendment to the Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended. On November 12, 2019, the board determined that the Morse High School Whole Site Modernization Project was exempt from environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities, and 15314 – Minor Additions to Schools. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Exemption (NOE)(Attached) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County, which was completed on November 13, 2019. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the approval of the proposed amendment is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the referenced NOE, and no further CEQA review is required.

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the Oak Park Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project has been adequately analyzed by the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Consistency Evaluation Process, as allowed by Section 15168(c)(2) of the State CEQA Guidelines, and that no further environmental documentation is required; and Approve Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company to provide preconstruction services for the Oak Park Elementary School Whole Site Modernization (Lease-Leaseback) CC22-0695-39. The term of this Agreement is effective March 23, 2022 and continues until the Project is complete. The preconstruction services for Oak Park Elementary School will complete the construction design and Division of the State Architects (DSA) approved plans and specifications and will be bid out to subcontractors by SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company. District staff will submit amended Agreements to the board for the construction of the project, which will increase the total guaranteed maximum price (GMP) for the Agreements.

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed Preconstruction Services: $165,766.00. Budget String: 9223-90502-00-6230-8500-0000-2500-8665.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On November 10, 2020, the board adopted a resolution for procedures for evaluating the qualifications of lease-leaseback contractors and the issuance of a request to prequalify for Group F, which are projects at or below $26,000,000.00 in estimated value. On November 12, 2020, the district issued a Request to Prequalify and for Statements of Qualification for Preliminary and Construction Services (RFQ) for Group F Lease-Leaseback Projects.

 

On December 17, 2020, 16 contractors submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQs) to the district’s RFQ. After evaluating each of the SOQs under the established criteria and procedures, District staff determined that 13 of the contractors met the requirements of the RFQ for Group F Projects. From those 13 qualified contractors, the district issued a subsequent Request for Proposal ("RFP") for Preconstruction Services for the Lewis Middle School Whole Site Modernization Phase 1 project, utilizing the lease-leaseback delivery method under Education Code section 17406 et seq. The best value criteria for scoring proposals included, but was not limited to, demonstrated competence, relevant experience, compensation, timeliness, and staffing capacity to perform the required work.

 

Sealed proposals to the RFP were due and received on February 10, 2022. The district received a total of two proposals from Balfour Beatty Construction and SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company.

 

Based on the strengths of the proposal submitted, SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company has been determined to provide the best value to the district. The remaining firm was ranked in descending order based upon their proposal. SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company is deemed a responsive and responsible proposer for this project, which is located at Oak Park Elementary School, 2606 - 54th St, San Diego, CA 92105.

 

This project consists of Preconstruction Design Services of the following:

The Oak Park Elementary School was original built in 1951 and consisted of 4 buildings: Multipurpose Building 1, Classroom/Administration Building 2, Classroom Building 3, and Classroom building 4. In 1957, Classroom building 5 was constructed. And in 2005, the library Building 6 was added. The site includes 22 modular buildings including one restroom relocatable. The campus site has undergone several modernizations through the years including accessible upgrades and campus-wide HVAC. While the school received extensive upgrades and improvements over the years, the Long Range Facility Master Plan showed that the site needs significant improvements. Based on the comprehensive planning study, the district concluded that Oak Park Elementary School is to have a Whole Site Modernization, including renovation of the existing Administration area, site improvements including new on-site staff parking and student pick-off and drop-off area, and construction of three new classroom buildings (music, kindergarten and general education).

The design of the whole site modernization project at Oak Park Elementary School needs to be further developed.  The scope which is not completely developed in the drawings (currently at the Design Development Phase), is described in the Specification Section, 01 10 00 Summary in the Design Development drawings and specifications, and will be required as part of the contract.  Once the design is completed, the Project Documents will require DSA review and approval before construction of this work can begin.  Other agency review and approval are also required for this project. Public Improvements work adjacent or:#333333"> (Proposed Project) is subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA). A Subsequent Document Environmental Checklist (Attachment 1) for the San Diego Unified School District Capital Improvement Program, Final Program EIR (SDUSD CIP Program EIR) was prepared for the Proposed Project, which documents that no new environmental analysis is required, that the Proposed Project is consistent with the certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR, that all applicable SDUSD CIP Program EIR mitigation measures are made conditions of the Proposed Project approval, and that the CEQA obligation of the Proposed Project has been met by the previously certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR.

As described in the attached Subsequent Document Environmental Checklist and the attached CEQA findings in connection with the approval of the Proposed Project (Attachment 2), the Proposed Project is within the scope of the adopted SDUSD CIP Program EIR, certified by the Board on July 27, 2021. The certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR was completed in accordance with CEQA and the State CEQA Guidelines. Further, the certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR remains pertinent and continues to have strong informational value. The Proposed Project has undergone a Consistency Determination process in accordance with CEQA Guidelines 15168(c)(2) to determine whether such changes in the project, circumstances, or information would trigger the need for any supplemental environmental documentation based on new or substantially more severe significant environmental impacts. After a thorough factual evaluation, staff has determined that no further supplemental environmental review is required because: 

  1. The Proposed Project is consistent with and within the scope of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR.
  2. The potential environmental impacts of the Proposed Project, including cumulative impacts, were fully considered in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR.
  3. All SDUSD CIP Program EIR mitigation measures applicable to the Project (i.e., all Programmatic Mitigation Measures of the Proposed Project), as identified in the Subsequent Document Environmental Checklist are made a condition of the Proposed Project's approval.
  4. The Proposed Project will not result in environmental effects that were not adequately examined in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR. The Proposed Project will incrementally contribute to, but will not substantially increase the severity of, significant environmental impacts previously identified in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR.
  5. All potentially significant effects on the environment due to the implementation of the Proposed Project have been eliminated or substantially lessened where feasible through SDUSD CIP Program EIR mitigation measures adopted in connection with the board's approval of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR and incorporated as part of the Proposed Project.
  6. All remaining significant and unavoidable environmental effects of the Proposed Project continue to be acceptable due to the reasons set forth in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR Findings and Statement of Overriding Considerations adopted by the Board in connection with its approval of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR Final EIR, and in the Findings and Statement of Overriding Considerations adopted by the board in connection with the approval of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR Final EIR, as referenced and reaffirmed herein.
  7. In accordance with Section 15168(c)(2) of the State CEQA Guidelines, none of the circumstances described in Section 15162(a) of the State CEQA Guidelines is present, and no further environmental review or documentation is required for the Proposed Project.

 

Approval of the project authorizes staff to file the Finding of Consistency Form (Attachment 3) with the Recorder/County Clerk of San Diego County, California, and Governor’s Office of Planning and Research, State Clearinghouse and Planning Unit and approves the Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company to provide preconstruction services for the Oak Park Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project.

22. Determine that the Joint Use Agreements with the City of San Diego at Chavez Elementary and Kimbrough Elementary are Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act Guidelines Sections 15301 Existing Facilities and 15323 Normal Operations of Facilities for Public Gatherings; and Approve Joint Use Agreements with the City of San Diego at Chavez Elementary, Kimbrough Elementary, King-Chavez Arts and Athletics and Sequoia Elementary; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
N/A

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the Joint Use Agreements with the City of San Diego at Chavez Elementary and Kimbrough Elementary are Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities and 15323 – Normal Operations of Facilities for Public Gatherings; and Approve new Joint Use Agreements (Agreements) with San Diego Unified and the City of San Diego (City) for the construction, operation, and maintenance of natural grass playfields, parking and recreation facilities at the following sites:

 

  • Chavez Elementary - 1404 S. 40th St., San Diego, 92113 (SV22-0817-99, Attachment 1)
  • Kimbrough Elementary - 321 Hoitt St., San Diego, 92102 (SV22-0816-99, Attachment 2)
  • King-Chavez Arts and Athletics - 415 - 31st St., San Diego, 92102 (SV22-0884-99, Attachment 3)
  • Sequoia Elementary - 4690 Limerick Ave., San Diego, 92117 (SV22-0883-99, Attachment 4)

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not Applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These Agreements will provide joint use at the following sites:

 

  1. Chavez Elementary: 2.6 acres joint use facility with 1.7 acres of natural grass playfield, backstops, asphalt hardcourts and play equipment. This new 25-year agreement replaces expired agreement executed on July 2, 1996.
  2. Kimbrough Elementary: 1.2 acres joint use facility with 0.96 acres of natural grass playfield, backstops, and asphalt hardcourts. This new 25-year agreement replaces expired agreement executed on July 2, 1996.
  3. King-Chavez Arts and Athletics: newly re-constructed 2.5 acres joint use facility with 1.6 acres of synthetic turf playfield, synthetic walking track, asphalt hardcourts and play equipment. This new 10-year agreement replaces expired agreement executed on July 25, 1991.
  4. Sequoia Elementary: newly constructed 4.9 acres joint use facility with 3.43 acres of natural grass playfield, decomposed granite walking track, backstops, picnic tables and drinking fountain.

 

Chavez Elementary, Kimbrough Elementary and Sequoia Elementary

 

The City will operate and maintain the three above listed joint use fields for the contract term, while the district will maintain landscaped areas outside of the joint use area and all perimeter fencing.

 

Usage of each of these joint use areas is as follows, with any modifications being mutually agreed upon by district and City staff to accommodate each site’s specific needs:

  • Each day school is in session, the district has exclusive use of the area 30 minutes prior to the beginning of the school day until 30 minutes after the dismissal bell.
  • Each day school is in session, the City will have use of the area up to 30 minutes prior to the beginning of the school day and 30 minutes after the dismissal bell.
  • City shall have exclusive use of the area on holidays, weekends and other days when school is not in session.

 

King-Chavez Arts and Athletics

 

District will provide maintenance of the synthetic turf field and walking track. City will reimburse district 50 percent of incurred costs for maintenance and repairs. City will operate the joint use field for the contract term.

 

Usage of each of this joint use area is as follows, with any modifications being mutually agreed upon by district and City staff to accommodate each site’s specific needs:

  • Each day school is in session, the district has exclusive use of the hardcourt area until 30 minutes after the dismissal bell and exclusive use of the synthetic turf field until 6:00 p.m.
  • Each day school is in session, the City will have use of the hardcourt area 30 minutes after the dismissal bell and exclusive use of the synthetic turf field after 6:00 p.m.
  • City shall have exclusive use of the entire joint use area on holidays, weekends and other days when school is not in session.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: On June 26, 2018, the board approved a resolution adopting a Final Mitigated Negative Declaration (MND) and adopting a Mitigation Monitoring and Reporting Program for the King-Chavez Primary, Arts, and Athletics Academies Whole Site Modernization (WSM) Project, which included the construction and operation of a joint use field. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Determination (Attachment 5) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County and the California State Clearinghouse, Office of Planning and Research, which was completed on June 27, 2018. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed joint use agreement is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the above referenced IS/MND, and no further California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) review is required.

 

On October 29, 2019, the board determined that the Multi-Campus WSM Project at Linda Vista, Sequoia, and Wegeforth Elementary School was exempt from environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15314 – Minor Additions to Schools. Specifically, the WSM at Sequoia Elementary School included the construction and operation of a natural turf joint use field. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Exemption (NOE)(Attachment 6) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County, which was completed on October 30, 2019. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the approval of the proposed joint use agreement is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the referenced NOE, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

The approval of the proposed Joint Use Agreements with the City of San Diego at Chavez Elementary School and Kimbrough Elementary School (Proposed Project) are subject to CEQA, however, are exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections 15301 (Class 1) – Existing Facilities and 15323 (Class 23) – Normal Operations of Facilities for Public Gatherings.

 

Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of use beyond that existing at the time of the lead agency’s determination (CEQA Guidelines §15301). The Proposed Project includes the approval of new joint use agreements for both school sites that would result in negligible expansion of the existing joint use area and would not result in any operational changes compared with the existing use. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 Exemption is appropriate.

 

Class 23 consists of the normal operations of existing facilities for public gatherings for which the facilities were designed, where there is a past history of the facility being used for the same or similar kind of purpose.  Past history is defined as a similar kind of activity that has been occurring for at least three years and that there is a reasonable expectation that the future occurrence of the activity would not represent a change in the operation of the facility (CEQA Guidelines §15323). The Proposed Project includes the approval of new joint use agreements to replace existing, expired agreements, to support recreational uses by students and residents. Both sites have had joint use facilities since 1996. Therefore, the application of a Class 23 Exemption is appropriate.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines section 15300.2): The Proposed Project does not have the potential to trigger any of the exceptions identified in CEQA Guidelines §15300.2 prohibiting the use of a categorical exemption.

  1. Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the project is to be located – a project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant. Therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the project may have an impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies.
  2. Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant.
  3. Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances.
  4. Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. This does not apply to improvements that are required as mitigation by an adopted negative declaration or certified EIR.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code.
  6. Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource.

 

Environmental Review: The following provides review of the potential environmental issues associated with the Proposed Project to ensure that the above exceptions are not applicable.

  1. Location. The Proposed Project would occur entirely within the boundaries of two existing school sites within existing joint use areas. The Proposed Project would not extend into any offsite or open space areas that may be classified as an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  2. Cumulative Impact. There are no known future projects proposed at both project sites or in within the vicinity of each site, when combined with operation of the Proposed Project, would result in a cumulatively considerable effect on the environment. Operation of the joint use facilities is consistent with existing use and would not contribute to a cumulatively considerable impact. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  3. Significant Effect. The Proposed Project includes approval of joint use agreements for existing recreational uses. No construction activity is proposed on- or off-site that could result in impacts to sensitive vegetation or other environmentally sensitive areas. As such, there is nothing unusual about the existing school sites and joint use areas, or surrounding areas. Operation of the joint use facilities would be consistent with existing use. Therefore, there is no reasonable possibility that the Proposed Project would have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances, and this exception does not apply to the project.
  4. Scenic Highways. The Proposed Project would not result in the construction of new facilities that would directly, or indirectly, affect an officially designated scenic highway or scenic resources near a scenic highway. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. According to the California State Water Resources Control Board Geotracker database, the project site is not located on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  6. Historical Resources. The Proposed Project does not require the demolition of existing historical era buildings or structures. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the Project.

 

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached NOE (Attachment 7) with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the proposed Joint Use Agreements, as described above, with the City of San Diego.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858-637-3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

25. Determine that the Roof Repair at District Physical Plant Operations Building is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 Existing Facilities; and Agreement with Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction for Roof Repairs at Physical Plant Operations; BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

$815,050.00
Budgeted
Yes

Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the roof repair at the district's Physical Plant Operations Building is exempt from further environmental review pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction for roof repairs at Physical Plant Operations (CP22-0760-39). The term of the Agreement is March 25, 2022 through completion of the project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $815,050.00. Budget String: 9609-90504-00-5751-8500-0000-21500-8XXX.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The roof repairs at Physical Plant Operations project consists of the following: Installation of new PVC roofing over existing vaulted standing seam metal roofs, replacement of built-up roofing at existing flat roofs. Installation of metal roof panels over existing skylight roof panels. Restoration of existing standing seam metal roofs.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on February 17, 2022. The district received a total of five bids from Best Contracting Services, Inc., Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction, Courtney, Inc., Letner Roofing, and Sylvester Roofing Company, Inc. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction, submitted a three percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The proposed activity is a project subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. (CEQA Guidelines §15301]). The Proposed Project involves roof repairs to an existing facility. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located – a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities and would not result in cumulative construction impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no exterior physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in impacts to existing historical resources. The Physical Plant building was constructed in 1992 and not eligible as a historic resource. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7151, jhensley@sandi.net]

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These transactions are submitted to the board for review pursuant to Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 and under its delegation of authority to the district Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Officer. To allow for efficiency in the administration of a large urban school district, California Education Code section 17605 specifically allows a school district to delegate limited purchasing power, i.e., for purchases no greater than $99,100.00 (for the year 2022) for supplies, materials, apparatus, equipment, non-construction services not greater than $99,100.00, and construction services less than $15,000.00. For this reason, these types of transactions must be reviewed by the board within 60 days of the date of the transaction under Education Code section 17605. Pursuant to the authority delegated to the district Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Officer on June 22, 2021, these purchase orders have been released to the respective vendors and are being submitted for review by the board at this time. Additionally, the attached agreements were signed pursuant to the delegation of authority and, as required by Education Code section 17604, must be approved or ratified by the Board of Education. The district has met the requirements of Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 with this process of reporting out the specified purchase orders under $99,100.00 (for the year 2022) that are not associated with any previously-approved board contracts and the ratification of contracts signed under delegation of authority.

Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$325,537.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
American Rescue Plan Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with San Diego State University Foundation to provide the district with a social worker to oversee the implementation of Project RISE UP (PS22-0627-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is January 11, 2022 through June 30, 2026, with the period of performance contingent on available District funding for the social worker position. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $325,537.00. Budget Strings: 5660-56320-00-5853-3110-0000-01000-0000 (first $25,000.00); 5660-56320-00-5100-3110-0000-01000-0000 (remaining $300,537.00). For the time period of 10/1/2024 through 6/30/2026, as applicable, budget string(s) will be determined at a later date, contingent upon available District funding. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: San Diego State University Foundation will provide the district with a social worker to oversee the implementation of Project RISE UP.

 

Project RISE UP is focused on:

  • Resilience building in schools through tutoring and professional development focused on trauma informed care practices that foster students resilience;
  • Increasing awareness of the rights and needs of students experiencing homelessness among schools and community agencies;
  • Streamlining and expanding support to youth and families by strengthening partnerships with community partners, as well as key departments within the school;
  • Expanding outreach efforts to increase enrollment for PK-12, with an emphasis on preschool aged children that are experiencing homelessness;
  • Upgrading the coordination and distribution of supplies to students in need; and,
  • Policy and procedures clarity and training in order to provide excellent level of services to youth and families experiencing homelessness.

 

[Originator/Contact: Michele Einspar, Program Manager, Leadership and Learning, 619.262.2483, meinspar@sandi.net]

Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,500,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Funds and Title I Arts Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Jessica Baron dba Guitars in the Classroom to provide the district with supplemental arts and music integrated residencies, assemblies, master classes, and professional development to K-12 school sites (PS22-0220-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is October 1, 2021 through September 30, 2026. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $1,500,000.00.

Budget Strings: 

Various Site Funds, $1,000,000,00.00

5446-30101-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000, $500,000.00

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Jessica Baron dba Guitars in the Classroom (Guitars in the Classroom) will provide districtwide services to K-12 school sites. Services include supplemental arts and music integrated residencies, assemblies, master classes, and professional development services. Guitars in the Classrooms programs uniquely integrate guitar and ukulele playing, singing, and songwriting whereby the musical instruments become an alternative vehicle for students, including English Learners and students with special needs, to access learning in areas such as literacy, math, and social emotional learning. Professional development focuses on building classroom teachers' capacity in musicianship and music integrated instruction in an "I do, we do, you do model that builds teachers capacity through leveled programs.

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

Subject
39. Ratification of Agreement with San Diego State University Research Foundation (SDSURF) to Provide the National Center for Urban School Transformation (NCUST) Program for Johnson Elementary School; BUDGETED: YES, LCFF INTERVENTION SUPPORT FUNDS
Meeting
Mar 22, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$6,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
LCFF Intervention Support Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with San Diego State University Research Foundation (SDSURF) to provide the National Center for Urban School Transformation (NCUST) Program for an executive coach in support of Johnson Elementary School (PS22-0672-41). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement.  The term of this Agreement is August 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The Total not-to-exceed amount: $6,000.00.  Budget String: 0157-09800-00-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period August 1, 2020, through June 30, 2021: $4,800.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Agreement with San Diego State University Research Foundation (SDSURF) continues to provide the National Urban School Transformation (NCUST) Program mentoring and academic coaching support for Johnson Elementary, a magnet STEM school.  This service will be provided online due to the Covid-19 Pandemic, and available in-person when permitted by the State of California and approved by the district.

 

The NCUST Program assists urban school districts and their partners in transforming urban schools for all students to achieve academic proficiency, evidence a zeal for learning, and graduate prepared to succeed in post-secondary education, the workplace, and their communities.

 

During the 2021-22 school year, the NCUST coach will meet with the principal to improve the school culture and curriculum with instructional practices, including distance learning for increased student academic achievements.  These weekly meetings will achieve the goals aligned with the school's strategic plan and provide immediate feedback on the school's performance to adjust goals as staff and student needs arise.

 

These weekly coaching sessions will assist the principal in developing and sustaining a positive educational environment, setting high expectations for learning, building capacity with the staff, and providing access to challenging curricula for all students.  These coaching sessions will also assist in monitoring the implementation of engaging high-quality educational lessons for the school's success.

 

[Originator/Contact: Bruce Bivins, Area 1 Superintendent, 619.725.7254, bbivins@sandi.net]
